They're relevant to modern pop culture because they are easily self insertable and go through the same problems we do.

Plus, we live in a highly self conscious and emotionally stunted era right now. Brothers and sisters hugging, parents and children holding each other, this reminds the lonely people on social media how hollow their life is/has been. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178797763
It's an actual movie for real people to watch. Not a cultural mad libs cue for faggots to have watercooler trending conversations on twitter over. No one watches it to build social capital the way they do with marvel by acting like they're bearing witness to the MCU anytime a new avengers film comes out. They're literally watching the movie.

That entire cottage industry of "content" on the internet is just neurotically defensive in response to this because it's made up of incredibly fragile and neurotic freaks that need everyone around them to be constantly reinforcing their monoculture in order to not freak out. They're constantly tweeting and posting and memeing about their characters because that's their "happy place". Then suddenly they get reminded of the real world when all the people in it go to the theater to experience a different planet and a narrative about family and love that isn't marked by any self-doubt or insecurity to which they could relate, and they lose it bc they've been reminded of how meaningless their "happy place" really is.

The people that suffer from that post avatar depression stuff are an interesting comparison, cuz they feel that way after walking out of the theater and remembering that pandora isn't real. For the geeknerdfilmbuff "cultural impact" fandom crowd on twitter, all their favorite properties have an endless supply of content dominating every single platform, and it serves as a mental blanket for them. Avatar fans gets depressed because pandora ends the second you walk out of the theater, but marvel fans never leave MCU land, because their entire life is suffused with content related to their properties. Sure, avatar has toys, but it does not have an endless stream of youtube channels that go "subscribe for more from the world of marvel, don't miss any of our updates, and join the conversation on twitter". It's their bubble being popped when they realize they're actually not the real mainstream.

There's only so many times you can see someones stomach ripped open in shakycam in Saving Private Ryan before the moment loses its impact.
Thin Red Line is as impactful EVERY TIME you watch the movie. The difference is that while SPR is trying to say something about conflict, family, nationalism, morality, etc, TRL intentionally withholds judgement about all those things. While the key phrase to SPR is 'earn this', there is nothing comparable in TRL. If anything, it would be a detached, ruminating question: 'what IS this?' You are forced to make your own enterpretation and that is what causes so many to seethe at the movie.

>>178795769
Jurassic Park and The Lost World took themselves seriously. They had some light hearted moments, but nothing that wandered into farce (other than one or two moments from TLW, like the gymnastics gag). Jurassic Park 3 deliberately pushed more into farce (the Kirby's being silly characters, the talking raptor gag, the phone in the spino, the stinky poo dinosaur moment, many more jokes overall, the weird man-on-the-beach ending, etc), but it wore its "gimmicky sequel" design on its sleeves. It's weak as a Jurassic Park movie, but it was still fun, and had some great content in its own right. It was the black sheep of the original trilogy, but we all ate well on the mutton.

Jurassic World was itself, fine. Its biggest problem was that it was made at a time when big blockbuster movies had to be quippy tongue-in-cheek amusement park rides. It wanted to be a big important "Jurassic Park" movie, but it also didn't want to take itself seriously. It was part Jurassic Park re-imagining ("they're building a dinosaur theme park"), part Jurassic Park 3 "gimmicky sequel" (the I.Rex as the new Spino stand-in), part Marvel flick. And the result was ... fine. It was embarrassing as a Jurassic Park film, but it was an entertaining enough night out. The real problem is that it made a fuck-load of money, so the sequels doubled down on the bullshit rather than having to step back and try something a little more grounded. That's why the second movie was some fucked up hybrid of a Lost World rip-off and a Resident Evil movie, and the third movie was just ... fucked.

It's a franchise that really needs to keep itself grounded. The Jurassic World movies are the polar opposite of grounded.

>>178790057
>Sardinians would poison victims with oenanthe crocata, a type of hemlock, and tie them up so they start having muscle stiffness and constantly feel heightened terror and stress from the poison giving them risus sardonicus (the sardonic grin) and then they’d take them to the top of a cliff and throw them off of it, ensuring they’d be in a state of sheer panic and horror and pain and fear as they tumble down to their death.
This is not true.
I'm sardinian, and the truth is more complicated than that.
While it's true that oenanthe crocata is very common in sardinia, and that ritual murder was a common practice, it is to be specified that it was a form of euthanasia practiced on the very elderly and sick, and it was usually done with a large hammer or axe to give a quick and painless death.
The abjective "sardinian/sardonic" however is too old, we have the earliest source of it in the Odyssey, meaning there was a relationship between laughter/smile and Sardinia since at least the late bronze age, which brings some credibility to the practice you mentioned.
It's necessary to specify that even in the greek reporting it's still done on the elderly as a form of euthanasia. The elderly were willing to undergo it, and knew the youth would be as well in a few decades.
The purpose was not to maximize pain, but to divinize/honour the dying, due to the belief (which is present in some form of buddhism sects even today) that diying while laughing means laughing in the face of death / defeating death.
Way different than the aztec Tlaloc, who "fed on the tears of children" and so the killings were all sacrificial in nature, they required maximum pain and fear and the victim was always completely unwilling

>>178793823
Williams honestly transcends the films he scores. Spielberg was smart to let his music play freely across scenes; that gave his films a big boost.
Listening to Williams' scores it's clear he wrote music with the purpose of evoking the films entirety; he doesn't score scenes by the moment.

As a result his music doesn't often evoke particular scenes or moments, it makes you think of something larger in scope, or perhaps more abstract. It's clear Spielberg, Lucas, and other filmmakers have been lucky to have him, and it's also clear he's not just one of the top film scorers of all time, but indeed one of the greatest composers of all time.

In the end, Kaufman and Conti compromised, using Conti's second score as the final score. >>178796608
This. Every movie from Jurassic Park to Alien had a cultural impact. Its themes and ideas spread to other creators of influence, its imagery becomes synonymous with the time period. H.R. Giger's designs for Alien were aped by virtually every science fiction product (be it a video game, movie, book, comic etc.) for at least ten years after the fact. Its characters are remembered fondly, Ripley is often the first name that comes to mind when female protagonists are mentioned, the actors portraying them are elevated to stardom. Lines are quoted in a variety of contexts. Cultural impact basically means the movie had a lasting effect on people, it's a measurable way to quantify that they didn't completely forget they saw the film right after leaving the theater. Seeing as how James Cameron *used* to make extremely culturally impactful films (Terminators 1 and 2, Alien, even Titanic to an extent) that changed the landscape of cinema and culture around them, the fact that the Avatar films do not - they come and go without a single line recalled, image remembered or emotion felt, even their supposed technological impact largely amounts to a 3D gimmick that fizzled out in only a couple of years - is actually kind of stunning, and certainly worth noting.

>>178797054
They're both art, and they're directly inspired by each other. James Cameron is a fan of Paul W.S. Anderson's work, and Anderson literally shot Resident Evil: Afterlife and Retribution on the same camera system as Avatar. You look at both franchises and they're obviously pulling ideas from each other.

The motif in the Avatar films where Jake is dreaming, and he snaps his eyes open... That's from Resident Evil. Having the bad guy from the previous film come back, except he's a clone that doesn't remember dying... That's copied verbatim from Resident Evil.

They're both art. Resident Evil: Retribution is one of the most kino action films ever crafted. Avatar: The Way of Water is one of the most spiritual cinematic experiences of all time. But part of the difference is that Avatar costs way, way more. It can indulge in things the RE movies could only flirt with, like underwater 3D photography, or underwater fight scenes.

>Rex was stolen by criminals as a pup, but managed to escape and befriend a boy, where he helped to solve his first case with the boy.

>Initially, Rex and Moser share an apartment at Marokkanergasse 18, Wien-Landstraße, however the pair go house-hunting quite early in the series. The house they eventually find is owned by a man who does not want dogs there, however Rex is able to alert him to a gas leak and in gratitude he allows Moser and Rex to stay.

>Rex is frequently called upon to resolve difficult situations, including helping a young girl in shock, preventing a woman from committing suicide and helping to get Moser's mobile phone when a crime has been committed. As a huge fan of the Fast and Furious franchise, I can confidently say that Tokyo Drift is hands down the best film in the series. The driving scenes are intense and the characters are well developed and likable. The plot is engaging and the ending leaves you wanting more. The cinematography is top-notch and the music score perfectly sets the mood for each scene. Overall, Tokyo Drift is a thrilling ride from start to finish and I highly recommend it to any fan of action films. It truly deserves the title of the best film ever created.

It truly deserves the title of the best film ever created.

It is difficult to compare a modern film like Tokyo Drift to a work of antiquity, as they come from different time periods and cultural contexts. However, both Tokyo Drift and works of antiquity can be seen as storytelling devices that allow us to explore different themes and ideas.

One way to compare Tokyo Drift to a work of antiquity is through the theme of the hero's journey. The main character of Tokyo Drift, Sean, embarks on a journey of self-discovery and personal growth as he learns to navigate the underground world of street racing in Tokyo. This journey is similar to the hero's journey found in many ancient works, such as The Epic of Gilgamesh or The Odyssey, where the hero embarks on a journey and faces challenges that help him become a better person.

Another way to compare Tokyo Drift to a work of antiquity is through the theme of tradition versus innovation. In Tokyo Drift, Sean must navigate the traditional world of Japanese street racing while also incorporating his own style and techniques. This theme is also found in ancient works, such as in The Iliad where the Trojans and Greeks have different traditions and ways of fighting, but must also adapt to new situations.
Overall, while Tokyo Drift and works of antiquity may come from different time periods and contexts, they both explore timeless themes and ideas that continue to resonate with audiences today.

Paul Walker was a rising star in Hollywood, known for his good looks and natural charisma on screen. He had just landed the lead role in a blockbuster action film, and was feeling on top of the world.

But little did he know, his success had caught the attention of the Taliban, a devious group of terrorists who saw him as a symbol of Western decadence. They plotted to kill him as a way to send a message to the world.

One day, while out running errands, Paul was ambushed by a group of Taliban gunmen. They shot him at point blank range, killing him instantly.

The news of Paul's assassination sent shockwaves through Hollywood and beyond. The Taliban had never targeted an actor before, and the attack was seen as a blatant act of terror.

As the investigation into Paul's death unfolded, it became clear that the Taliban had been planning the attack for months. They had recruited a group of disillusioned young men to carry out the assassination, using the promise of glory and martyrdom to lure them in.

As the world mourned the loss of a talented actor taken far too soon, the hunt for his killers continued. Eventually, the perpetrators were brought to justice, and the world breathed a sigh of relief knowing that the Taliban would not be able to carry out such a heinous act again.

But the memory of Paul Walker lived on, as his films continued to entertain and inspire people all over the world. His legacy as a talented actor and a victim of terror would never be forgotten.

The film for sure tackles sexual awakening but people who think it's trying to make little girls whore is stupid. Her "selling the panda" isn't portrayed as a good thing. It's something that happens because she goes overboard with what can she do with newfound powers, it leads to her getting manipulated by another character who she then lashes out onto.
What the film does say that it can't be something that's compoletely her own fault, as she is a child (teen) and children are naturally unsatble and at her age maximalist. The main cause of it is her helicopter mother. The film is a coming-of-age feature but it's specifically about things that parents are afraid to talk about with their children, things they hide from them which leads to rejection and reckless behaviour. This includes sexual awakening, new type of relationships, new hobbies, newfound independence. The ending is about the mother learning to understand the cause of problems and Mei learning to be responsible with everything new that appeared in her life.
